Review title: Emotionally manipulative unrealistic use of wonderful Sarandon's time
Review_body: Seven members of my family went to see this movie at Christmas, because of an admiration for the cast and because of a divorce/remarriage situation within our family.  We left disappointed on both levels.  Although Sarandon and Roberts are wonderful (Harris seems to be phoning it in) the movie is too thin and unrealistic to support these women.  In summary, an ex-wife reluctantly accepts the role of her ex-husband's new fiancee in her children's lives, then learns to appreciate her when a crisis occurs.  There is potential, but the answers provided are too easy and lack context. Particuarly disappointing was the lack of context for all of these people. Where were the  grandparents, the siblings, the girlfriends?  If they were such great women, they should certainly have had more people in their lives. Without any context, the relationship between the two women is completely unrealistic.  The movie also goes inevitably for the melodrama and tears, without exploring elements of the changes in these people's lives which could have been more interesting.  There are far too many tearful scenes with the children, and far too few that demonstrate real understanding of life's difficulties, and particularly the challenges that the children face. I wish there were better scripts out there for these women.

I loved this film!It made laugh, it made me cry. It was a very touching film. I would recommend that you go and watch it if you get the chance, you won't be disappointed. I loved this movie, and I am sure you will too.

I saw this movie for the first time a few weeks ago and I Totally Loved it!, so much so, that I went out and purchased it soon afterwards...Susan Sarandon (as the mother) and Julia Roberts (as the soon-to-be stepmother) are both fantastic in their respective roles, and Ed Harris (as the father) is good too.It is beautifully shot- the city (of New York) and the surrounding- more country-fied area's of New York look great, the contrasts as the seasons change are, quite simply, Stunning. Glorious!

Review title: Sing "Glory" you were saved from the funeral

Review title: Overall a great movie, but has many flaws...
Review_body: For starters the mother (Jackie Harrison played by Susan Sarandon) is just horridly mean to nearly everyone around her, I ended up completely hating the character and waiting for her to die already, which I would HOPE was not the intention of the film. She did soften up considerably at the end, but it was too little too late as far as I'm concerned. The daughter (Anna Harrison played by Jena Malone) was a snot-nosed brat who I wanted to strangle at times, but also cooled off and much better than her mother's character.Most of the background including the dad (Luke Harrison played by Ed Harris) seemed to disappear from the film completely as it started to center around the two women fighting for/over these two children. The rock and roll songs were nice (a bit repetetive but Im sure Sonny and Cher fans will like it) but the score was inappropriate and its better to just tune it out.All that being said this is STILL a great movie, an 8 or 9/10. Very touching story with good heart, even if it dosen't get its point across too well at times. The little boy (Ben Harrison played by Liam Aiken) is VERY cute and funny, a very promising young actor. But by far the best thing in this movie is Julia Roberts as Isabel Kelly. She has it all in this film and simply steals the show. If she performed this good all the time more people would take her seriously.If you ever feel the need to cry, smile, or simply hate a character and yell at the screen, give this move a chance. :)

Review title: Look out! The PTA might complain about this movie...
Review_body:
This poorly written film contains ridiculous exposition to link together the often contrived scenes.  Here are some examples:#1  When Julia Roberts phones Harper Collins, a major New York publisher, a senior editor answers the phone.  Hmm, I guess the receptionist was too busy editing the screenplay for Stepmom.#2  Later in the film, Julia Roberts discovers a personal letter written by a friend of Susan Sarandon on Harper Collins letterhead.  Wow!  It really doesn't appear that that Harper Collins is running a very tight ship!#3  After the 12 year old daughter in the film embarrasses an ex-boyfriend by pretending to date a high-school aged model, Susan Sarandon yells at Julia Roberts for allowing this incident to take place because she's "gonna have to deal with the numerous complaints at the PTA as a result of this incident".  Huh?  What?????#4  The 12 year old daughter (who was 4 during Pearl Jam's heyday) is giddy to see cynical grunge-rockers Pearl Jam WITH HER MOM.
The only reason to cry during this movie is that the screenwriters who wrote it probably got paid more than each crying member of the audience.

I go to movies expecting to have fun and be entertained.  Two hours of sadness brought on by broken marriages, angry children, and cancer is not what I would call fun entertainment.  This movie's about as enjoyable as visiting a hospital. 3/10

Review title: Though your candle shines on others, it does not shine less on you.
Review_body: One of the best character studies I have ever seen. A film that handles the "divorce" subject without the cliche's, giving a seldom approached solution for healing a broken heart. Excellently brings out the emotional challenges a family has when the parents divorce.The husband is living with a younger woman.  The 12 yr. old daughter senses her mother's pain & rejects the girlfriend. The mother tries to control her bitterness for the sake of her children, but can't really get a grip. The father trying to keep peace between all of them. And then the younger woman (Julia Roberts) does all that she can to try and be a "part" and not the "other woman" that's destroying a family.Usually in such a film, you're cheering for the "dumped" partner, and "boo"ing the other one. But not in "Stepmom". You have the feeling like, "Hey, I can relate to everybody's point of view here."  The actors also have to get the credit. They did a marvellous job of portraying their characters.The message? With a bit of time, patience and trying to understand, unselfish love can change any situation and heal any pain.  It shows how forgiveness makes these changes possible & shows the benefits you receive in recognizing the mistakes you yourself have made. To accept the outcome, to accept people's choices rather than fight against them.  To put the happiness of those you say you love, first, and then joy replaces your misery.I don't know if there is such a thing as a "perfect" movie, but this one sure comes close.

Review title: One of the worst movies I've ever seen
Review_body: This is one of the worst movies I have even seen. What were they thinking.? If the characters aren't arguing in the movie, they are crying. Then the writers have to add *spoiler* the whole cancer thing just to make the audience feel sorry and end up crying in the end. That's one thing I hate about movies is when they try to make you feel sad instead of using real emotions and situations to make real drama. It's just one big piece of crap.

Review title: Very Entertaining, but no Oscar winner
Review_body: I thoroughly enjoyed this film. Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts give excellent performances as the mother and stepmother of two highly likable kids. Ed Harris's performance is kind of flat, but I blame this more on the script than on his ability as an actor. The story is about how a family reacts to one divorced parent getting remarried, in this case Ed Harris and Julia Roberts move in together and it causes tensions for everyone. Sarandon and the kids start out hating Isobel (Roberts) to the point that Sarandon (I keep forgetting her character's name) doesn't even want Isobel to be alone with the children. The story is very real. I can only imagine how an ex-wife would feel when her husband moves in with another woman. I have personally lived the role of the children. My father got remarried to a beautiful, younger woman when I was growing up and I wasn't particularly thrilled. The children in the movie remain fiercely loyal to their mother and adopt her attitudes about Isobel. At one point the son says to Sarandon something like, "I can hate her (Isobel) if you want me to." What makes the movie so real is that while Sarandon and Isobel eventually become civil with one another, they never become best friends. If they had the film would have lost all credibility with me.(SPOILER ALERT, although this plotline is in all the reviews) Sarandon's character has cancer and as the films goes on we begin to understand that Isobel will end of being more than just a STEPmother. While her relationship starts out on a bad note with the kids, (especially the daughter) it's a no-brainer that as the movie goes on she'll win their hearts. But it's the way she wins their hearts that's very believable. It doesn't happen overnight. I did have a problem with Sarandon's bitchiness toward Isobel. She was relentless. In one scene Isobel asks Sarandon if she could take the daughter to a Pearl Jam concert on a school night, as a way to try and get closer to her. Sarandon says no. A few scenes later Sarandon whips out tickets to the concert right in front of Isobel and snottily says to her, "Thanks. It was a great idea." This kind of thing, while believable, didn't endear me to Sarandon, and at that point in the film if was time for her to change her attitude.All five actors give excellent performances and as I said, the plot is very believable. This film has everything: comedy, drama, romance, family values. I highly recommend it to anyone, but it will really hit home with people who've lived through a similar situations.

Review title: Moving drama with a great performance by Julia Roberts
Review_body: I waited a good three weeks after Stepmom premiered before I seen it.  The previews made it seem a bit to sickeningly sweet.  Well, after seeing the movie, I have to report that it is sickeningly sweet.  But, I liked it anyway.The story predictably tugs at all the right heartstrings.  Not only does it milk the stepmother situation for all it's worth, but it also throws in a terminal disease for good measure.What saves this movie from mediocrity are the characters and the performances.Everyone is appealing.  Ed Harris does his typical class act job. Although for the most part, his job seems to be just staying out of the way of the two female leads.  The two female leads do a wonderful job.  Julia Roberts brings beauty and humor to her role.  Susan Sarandon brings dignity and class to hers.  They make a good match.The actors playing the kids are exceptional.  Jena Malone, as the daughter/ step-daughter does a particularly wonderful job.  There are moments in the movie where you'd like to slap her, and there are others where your heart really goes out to her.This type of movie is not generally the kind of movie I'd go for.  Normally I like car chases and aliens.  But, this sweet little movie was able to hold my interest and occasionally have me feel for the characters.A small winner.  7 out of 10.

*Minor spoilers ahead*Julia Roberts strikes again!  Basically, this film is a big ol' sticky wad of total melodrama about a bunch of snobby, spoiled rich people throwing tantrums whenever they don't get their own way.  It's supposed to teach the audience something about growing up and bonding with stepparents and coping with divorce and terminal illness and a whole slew of other things, but in the end it's just stupid, contrived and stereotypical.  All three of the female characters (Jackie, Isobel and Anna) are self-absorbed, rude and manipulative and the younger child (I forget his name) is supposed to be all cute and handsome and charismatic and blah-de-blah but instead he quickly becomes annoying.  Anyway, the plot basically goes round and round in circles for the first forty-five minutes and then the writers realized that it wasn't going anywhere and decided to deal the Tearjerking Terminal Illness(tm) card just to wrap it up.  So they have Susan Sarandon's character get cancer, resulting in a half-million Heartwrenching Goodbye Sequences(tm) which ultimately bring the family closer together.  I have a lot of respect for many of the actors in this film, but in all honesty, the film itself was way too cheesy for me to stomach (no pun intended).  If you're a big fan of any of the actors, it's probably worth it, though.

Review title: A weepie, but a good one
Review_body:
This isn't my sort of film at all - I normally don't go for weepies - but I found I really loved it. Mostly that's due to Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts, who are both excellent, but also because it's an interesting and moving take on family roles, relationships and clashes.I've seen quite a few reviewers on here slate the film because they didn't like how the characters behaved or the choices they made (especially the father). I think that misses the point of the film. It's true, none of the characters are faultless - they lash out when they're hurt or scared, they sometimes set bad examples for the children, they make selfish mistakes because they're afraid and they get stuck in roles that they've adopted and then complain about them.
In other words they're human - messily, brokenly human and they have messy, difficult relationships. For me that's one of the strengths of the film, not a weakness, and I think all the cast do a good job of making the characters still sympathetic, even though they don't always behave well.In the end what I really love about this film is the development of the film's central relationship between Sarandon and Roberts. The relationship is adversarial at first with the two women at loggerheads because the ex-wife still feels hurt by the breakdown of her marriage and defensive about a new woman in her children's life, while the girlfriend resents living in the shadow of her boyfriend's previous relationship and being rejected by his children. Added to that the two are very different women with different values - so what sort of example is being set for the children is also a bone of contention.
The two women are gradually negotiating their way through that minefield when the ex-wife's cancer prognosis forces them to communicate and find common ground for the sake of the children.It's an unashamedly soppy ode to the strong relationships women can develop when they aren't competing over men and is genuinely moving. The closing shot of the film is a real tearjerker and makes all the rows and misunderstandings that went before worthwhile

I found this movie disappointing. The battle between the ex-wife/mom and the new, younger girlfriend could have been a good movie. I don't appreciate that cancer in the family brings people together and functions as a shortcut to resolving conflict. Susan Sarandon ends up passing the torch gracefully to her replacement mom, Julia Roberts. It just seems too morally perfect. I found it sappy. But, of course, how can they resent each other when Susan Sarandon is dying, right? Hopefully, in reality, people find reasons other than grave illness to treat each other with respect and move on from a conflict. There's something either very romantic or very cynical about the movie's implication that mortal illness brings out the best in someone.

Review_body: To fully understand why this movie is not as tacky as you think

Review title: The best movie of all time!
Review_body: Although not out on video yet, 'Stepmom' is the best movie ever. I have seen it in the theatre 9 times, and look VERY forward to it coming out on video on April 27th. Susan Sarandon did a FABULOUS job on this movie. Her passion really let out on this one. Julia Roberts also did an incredible job, but I have to say Susan blew this one over the top. Liam Aiken was a sweetie, but Jena Malone I did not like. A good actress, but yet too bratty. (No offense) Ed Harris was great also, as he always is, such a great man. Crying all 9 times, this movie is a real tear jerker, and being 13 years old I don't cry that often. But this is very sad, be sure to bring tissues, you'll regret it if you don't. This is an incredible movie, and it should have been nominated for an Oscar, but unfortunately it didn't. This movie gets 10 stars and then some, and the 'Ain't No Mountain High Enough' performance was so great that we are performing it in chorus at school. The best movie ever!

This movie is kind of hard to watch, mainly because I hate Susan Sarandon's character. She's mean-spirited, self-righteous, and self-centered. She's mad at her ex-husband, so she takes it out on Julia Roberts' character. This is understandable, but she does it at the expense of her children's well-being. She basically makes her family dysfunctional. When she finally dies of cancer, I don't feel bad for her. I feel bad for her kids. They're okay, although the girl is sometimes extremely unlikable. What bothers me is, they act like everything is okay because Susan Sarandon's character is dying. That would not happen in real life. That said, the movie is overall good. It's not boring, and it's touching if you can forget what a horrible person the mother is.

This movie has lots of potential but constantly falls short.  Susan Sarandon is so talented, it's a shame to see her wasted in a boring role like this. Julia Roberts has aility, but she annoys the heck out of me.There's so much in this film that is hard to swallow--most especially the ridiculously unrealistic "revenge" taken against a little girl's teaser at school.  Come on!!!  That would never happen.THe film looks good, but says nothing except "Can't we all just get along?" Nothing new.

You'd have to be really cold-blooded not to get choked up at a few points in this film, but it is shamelessly manipulative, subtle as a jackhammer exercise in excess. These characters are rich, spoiled and uninteresting, and you really don't care what happens to them. They live in beautiful homes (why couldn't they be REAL people?) and seem to have no problems except for the tension between Sarandon, Roberts and Jena Malone. It took five writers to come up with pap like this? Sarandon is much better than the material. It's a shame that she and Roberts, who were executive producers, settled for such TV-movie of the week material.

They showed this movie on the bus from Amherst to New York. It hurt. It hurt a lot. The squealing little moppet, the two dimensional characters, the overused plot contrivances, the steriotypes, the hideous music, the pathetic attempt at emotional manipulation, the... the "dialogue" if that's what it can be called... How bad was it? Well, the bus was delayed, so they showed "Money Train", too. And after the horror that was "Step Mom", "Money Train" actually felt like a breath of fresh air.I got to see "Step Mom" on the way back, too. Thanks, "Peter Pan"!

I went expecting a comedy of sorts, but found myself immersed in a heart-wrenching tear-jerker instead.Susan Sarandon is wonderfully expressive as the mother/ex-wife who's always been there for everyone.  A woman who has sunk so deep into the role of supporter that she has trouble admitting to her family that she needs to be on the receiving end for once.I loved the relationship she had developed with her son - too often children in films are merely props, and there's rarely the depth and individuality expressed in this film.Julia Roberts was hilarious as the fiancee/career woman who is more used to last-minute creative solutions than planning ahead.   I would like to have seen her character developed a little more outside of the family ties......Friends?  Family?  Interests other than photography?Ed Harris's role was a travesty......his influence was practically non-existent other than to explain why Sarandon & Roberts couldn't get rid of each other.  I was disappointed that his character was allowed to be so translucent.   It  takes a lot of courage and strength to create a strong friendship out of a failed marriage - the respect, love and character that must exist to hold that bond were only hinted at, and I wonder if his gentle masculine influence was eclipsed intentionally to give "strong female" roles more screen time.By the way - for those who were wondering about snowblowing......think Altoids.

I had grown accustomed to Julia Roberts starring in light, fluffy comedies such as My Best Friend's Wedding and Pretty Woman.  "Stepmom" began in a similar light tone, but quickly developed into a thick drama.  I thought that Julia Roberts pulled off the part extremely well.  Susan Sarandon's portrayal as Jackie was excellent.The story was believable.   The main characters of Isabel and Jackie were both developed indepth.  The cruelty of Jackie and Anna towards Isabel could be discomforting at times!In the end, I had great respect for both characters for their remarkable abilities to overcome adversity, although in very different manners.Not to give it away, but Luke's technique of proposing marriage was extremely creative.  Wish that I had thought of it first!  I also enjoyed Jackie's Victorian style house.The drama became very thick and moving towards the end.   I couldn't help but to shed a tear at the climactic Christmas giftgiving scene.Overall, I thought that the movie was very good, and would strongly recommend it.  For those who've recently lost a loved one to cancer, I would recommend skipping this film as the subject matter is very serious.

I thought that the movie Stepmom was a moving and terrific film.It tells the story of a mother and her kids and how they relate to the children's dad remarrying again and how they handle this woman.Susan Sarandon is terrific as Jackie and she plays this part so well that she should have,in my opinion,been nominated for an Oscar.I thought that Julia Roberts did an excellent job as well as Isabel.When Jackie ends up with cancer,and you see how the family reacts to it,it's gets depressing to know that they are families that have to go through that and deal with someone who has cancer or maybe even deal with themselves.It's a movie about the unexpected.

This was a pretty predictable movie, and way, way too long.  The only reason for going to see it is Liam Aiken, who played the little boy.  What a find! He is a good actor (not just for his age), and totally charming and seemingly unspoiled.  I will be watching his career with interest.

I couldn't recommend this film to anyone.  As others have commented, the acting is good, but the characters in this film are unforgivably nasty to one another.Don't take your young girls to see this.  There is a miserably misguided scene of retaliation against a 12-year-old's ex-boyfriend that is really bad news.We could have used an intelligent film about the frequent stresses and infrequent joys of building a new kind of family, one that addressed the issues in a realistic way.  Yeah, I cried because Susan Sarandon is such a marvelous actress and she is amazingly real.  But I could also have cried for the sadness of these two powerful and intelligent women (Sarandon and Roberts) wasting their time and talents on this.

Review title: not great like you might expect
Review_body: ok ok i'm not a big fan of julia roberts formula movies and yet i did succumb to another 2 hours and 4 minutes of one.  i don't know why---maybe just because it's $20 million/movie julia roberts.  i do like her--- i think she is very talented and rightfully commands an audience but the scripts she's been reading recently are definatily second-class.  case in point--- "stepmom" was an alright film.  not great like you might expect from a fine director, chris columbus, ( "mrs. doubtfire", the "home alone" movies and my favorite, "adventures in babysitting"), and a great cast with roberts, susan sarandon, ed harris.  it's wonderfully directed---i loved the way dad (harris) plays a minor role and shows up only when needed (after all ---the movie is "stepMOM" ) and allows the "moms" to figure things out themselves. that's a lot of leeway for the direction and the relationship of the principal characters.  the acting is superb with both roberts and sarandon shining on cue, semi-reminiscent of "thelma and louise" with sarandon and geena davis only in a more adversarial way.  their scenes together are a real treat.  and you do even get to hate anna (jena malone)---the little brat !!  the scene stealer in the movie, however, is ben (liam aiken)----the biggest smile this side of julia roberts herself.  there's nothing really to harsh in this movie to bash too much except possibly the script itself. in a day and age when the extended family governs over half the population--there really wasn't anything most haven't seen or lived through themselves.  the cliches, stereotypes, routine range of family situations and levels of acceptances.  i give this movie a strong 6.5 based on great performances by roberts and sarandon and that worldly smile by aiken.

This movie is basically a fraction of how life can be that is why people can get into it and get emotionally evolved in the story. Julia Roberts and Susan Sarandons performance is excellent in my eyes it isn't the usual part for Sarandon or Roberts for that matters but they both stand out.Sarandon manages to annoy you in the beginning and at the end feel sorry for her. It is a great family movie and it also has it's good comedy moments. I definitely recommend it to everybody who likes true life movies. The movie always keeps you wanting to know what is going on and what's happening with the characters and look at every characters point of view!

Stepmom is a wonderful movie. A touching movie. A realistic movie.  I know how it is to lose a loved one. The movie really gets to your heart.  It's got many moods in it.  Happy, sad, serious and heart warming..   Must see!!!!

more than i thought i would...tear-jerker, in spots, but also has some cute spots too . . . very well acted . . . good soundtrack.

As a stepdad, I can relate a little to Stepmom, but I write this on behalf of my wife who, as a doting mother, cried for at least half of this movie. Susan Sarandon's performance was her usual top notch best and she, as probably only a mother could, gave a performance of astonishing honesty.  Ed Harris turned in another solid supporting performance and, even the toothy Julia Roberts lived up to at least some of her hype as the stepmom of the title.  This is an enjoyable movie with plenty of heart and proves the old adage:  You can choose your friends but you can't choose your family.  I think now we can say that also includes STEPMOMS (and dads)!!!

I don't want to sound harsh, but this movie bored my coke flat and my popcorn stale.  It bored me so bad that I had a fight with my girlfriend about emotions.  There is only one reason to rewatch this movie.  I want to do a scientific study of how many times one of the characters cried, or almost cried.  Now don't get me wrong, like my girlfriend did, emotions are necessary for a movie to be good.  I can't stand movies, and it seems to be either the French, if subtitles can be emotional, or Hollywood that make these movies, that are obviously trying to suck me in by squirting tears in my eye.  The whole movie was a magnanimous fairy tale.  I would have called it, "Trouble in Never-neverland."  Everyone lived in a beautiful house, with beautiful things, with lots of money, being beautiful themselves, having cute kids, having cool jobs, and even the damned dog was cute.  Blah!!  If someone in Hollywood is listening, drop the budgets and raise the quality. It's a good thing movies have a loud song during the ending credits to wake people up.Look to the horizon.  It is void of RIDERS.

I read a review calling this the '90s version of "Kramer vs. Kramer," but at least KvK was at the time fairly original. The two lead actresses tried valiantly to keep the film upright, but with a script like this, the effort was in vain.I have to admit that I did enjoy counting the continuity errors in this one (does anyone have a final count on how many different "engagement" rings Roberts ended up wearing?)

Review title: starts off badly and gets worse
Review_body: I shut this pandering piece of tripe off after trying to hang on for thirty minutes. There are many ways to tell this story, (remains of the day comes to mind) but they have chosen to make a soap opera out of real life issues. Take my advice give it a pass.

When I saw the trailer for Stepmom at the movie theater, I wanted to see it because it was believable. The parents are divorced and the father is engaged to a woman young enough to be his daughter. Jackie is jealous because Isabel is not a younger version of her and she may feel Anna and Ben will get close with her. My parents were never divorced, but for those whose parents are and remarried may know exactly what it's like to be in Anna and Ben's shoes. Before I saw the film I had no idea Jackie was going to get cancer and die. The trailer was poorly advertised. When Anna became fond of Isabel, Jackie resented their friendship because she felt as though she were being replaced. The ending was good because there was peace in the family and Jackie grew fond of Isabel and knew her children were going to be fine. The only thing I didn't like about Stepmom was that a woman Susan Sarandon's age playing a mother to a 12 year old and a 7 year old. After seeing this movie, I saw that being a childless Stepmom can be a lot of pressure.

A well written piece about the adjustment of two young children when a much younger woman becomes their stepmother.  Beautiful and well-written performances by Sarandon, Roberts and Harris make this an outstanding vehicle for all three. Jena Malone shines as a 12 year old girl going through the insecurity of her mom being replaced by a younger woman, and coping with growing up at the same time.  Liam Aiken is adorable as the young mischievous Ben, too young to quite understand it all, yet still creating his share of havoc for Roberts' character. Roberts and Sarandon make worthy adversaries, with the mom always tring to sway the kids' opinion, while the Stepmom just tries to learn how to be a parent, even though she never planned to be.Although I'm not usually big on family drama type movies, this one's a winner.  Many laughs, and a few sad scenes even pulled some tears.  Highly recommended!

Review title: I cried in spite of the plot
Review_body: Yes, Stepmom is a tear-jerker. I enjoyed it and didn't feel embarrassed about the tears, but on analysis, there were a lot of problems with the plot. What was it that changed the main protagonists' attitudes toward each other? Why did Mom fess up to her secret when she did? Did Stepmom end up just being the surrogate babysitter, or did she continue her career?I think the acting, pacing and especially the music had a lot to do with the emotional impact of most scenes, especially in the second half of this film. So go, cry, and try to ignore all those little things that drive a picky, analytical person crazy.

The acting was consistently good throughout the entire movie. Especially the surprisingly excellent job of acting done by Julia Roberts. I knew that Susan Sarandon was a good actress and I suspected that Julia Roberts might be from watching some things that she had done during an interview with David Letterman, but I was overwhelmed by how well the trio worked together to create a real family.

Review title: I was going to walk out of this one halfway through!
Review_body: Not because it was bad but because I was already crying so hard. I was only going to this movie because Julia Roberts and Susan Sarandon were in it, and am glad I did go because it touched me so deeply. Girls get your box of Kleenex you are going to need it!

Review title: A movie not to be miss!
Review_body: 1. A good movie. 2. A magnificent crew. 3. Marvellous acting. A movie which deserves more than oscar-winning actress Susan Sarandon been nominated in the Golden Globe.

Review title: APPLAUSE!!! Wake up! and remember the children!!!
Review_body: This film has a great plot and story line!  If it is manipulating, it is for our own good!  With all of the divorces out there, and all of the children caught in the middle (or forgotten altogether), we need movies like this to remind us of what is important:  our children, life, and friendship.When I first heard of Susan and Julia both in this movie, I couldn't picture them acting together.  They are both wonderful actresses, but so different. They did a damn fine job.  I wouldn't change a thing about this movie.  It is a big statement about our lives.  We need to put our kids in front of career and jealousy.  We need to work together to love them and bring them up happy and healthy!  I gave this movie a big 10!  and as for the puppy...it wasn't a Christmas present...and it was not a major part of the plot!

i read the reviews here, but still i watched this movie. thank god i did not pay anything. it has no redeeming features. i pity the people who worked on it, but that's no reason to pretend this film has any good points.it is mere schmaltz. if you have no critical faculties whatsoever and are a sucker for bourgoeis sentimentality [an american, and female] you will probably have a good weep and vote for this as your all time favourite.however, if you have the possibility of watching any other movie than this one, grab it.

Review title: Good acting, but badly overdrawn, psychologically inept writing
Review_body: In this maudlin, melodramatic fantasy, we have five main characters: The stepmom Julia Roberts), the mom (Susan Sarandon), the dad (Ed Harris), and two kids.  The stepmother's role is the only one of the male roles to emerge faintly from one dimension, to resemble a live person.  The mom is a controlling, spiteful, know-it-all, who also somehow manages to muster immense, flawless tenderness with her kids.  The dad is just good.  The daughter resembles a person; the son, some narcissist's self-image of himself in childhood, remarkably charming and good-natured.  As I watched it, I figured, "This was written by someone with a godawful, but dead, obsessive-compulsive mother to whom he was overly close in childhood, whom he feels bad about hating now, especially since he likes his stepmom so much." The performances are excellent, but the characters are so incredible that this is more cartoon than drama.  Some parts were so predictable and mawkish I just fastforwarded through them.

Review title: it literally made me cry and call my mom
Review_body:
A warm and yet so dramatic family movie.
considering the plot it's actually not a story about a cancer itself, even though it's playing a leading role in the lifetime of characters. first and foremost, it's a story about feelings - love, passion, compassion and resignation.
it's a story about every mom on the planet - the ones who give a birth and the ones who raise the kids.

This movie has been exhibited countless times in A&E for Latin America. And each time it is, I hate it more.The only characters I didn't want to punch and stab were the little boy and the future step mom: the dad was nonexistent and couldn't even try to hold his own against his mega-bitch of an ex-wife; the daughter was a whiny, lying, rude brat who YET AGAIN perpetuates the "Daddy's little girl who HATES every attractive woman next to him because Mommy Said So" stereotype; and Susan Sarandon's mom chara was one of the most overbearing, spiteful, misogynistic mother charas I've ever seen, who spoils her babies rotten to the point of making them completely detached from reality while practically abusing the unfortunate girl who's gonna "replace" her when she's gone, just because she commits the sin of being prettier, younger and with a modern mindset. And I'm supposed to feel sorry for her when she finally kicks the bucket, after all she has made others go through? Not even great actors like Sarandon, Harris and Roberts can save this pile of manipulative, cloying, fake, pseudo-deep crap.

Review title: A touching and honest telling of mixed families
Review_body: This movie honestly addresses the emotions and stories behind divorce, stepparents, and cancer. One of the strengths of this movie is that it does not vilify anyone. There is no evil stepparent, ex-wife, ex-husband, or stepchildren. You identify with every character, even when they act imperfectly. When the stepdaughter, Anna (Jena Malone) acts completely bratty towards stepmother Isabel (Julia Roberts), you do not only identify with Isabel at having to make the best of this situation. Your heart also goes out to Anna, a young child who is going through this tough time. It is Jena Malone's Anna that has the most touching lines. "You do not walk out on your mother!" Father goes. "No, that is your job." Simultaneously the insecurities of the normally perfect Jackie (Susan Saranadon) are understandable.The movie's only faults are that it sometimes overemphasizes points and it does not fully address its topic. By giving Jackie cancer it does not explore the complexities of a mixed family. Instead, it leaves you with the cop out. "You have their future, I have their past.Nevertheless, I love this film. Another great thing about this film is the acting. Julia Roberts, Susan Saranadon, and Ed Harris are known commodities as is Chris Columbus. However, the children actors, including Jena Malone, acted superbly. Therefore, I highly recommend this film.

The first two thirds of the film are quite clearly stated by the sixty-second trailer. The big screen, unexpurgated, version serves only to make these loathsome and hateful people (well portrayed by Susan Sarandon and Jena Malone) more substantial and more tangible. The events of the last third of the film are intended, I assume, to turn around our perception of these characters and somehow make them more endearing. Well, for me, it just didn't work. Although the acting was at least competent, the apparent moral of the story of absolute forgiveness under adversity was just not plausible.If you are a staunch Julia Roberts fan you may appreciate her portrayal of the unquestioning Isabel but are not likely to enjoy the abuse her character must endure.

Jena Malone (Anna) did some very good acting in this movie which she is not getting a lot of credit for. The moms were both did some great acting. It is about a family that has to deal with two very big problems.

Review title: This film will not live up to your expectations.
Review_body: This movie is basically self-explanatory. If you've seen thepreview, you know what it's about. But, there's one thing thepreview doesn't state: this movie won't live up to yourexpectations. Although it may seem like a funny, entertaining,possibly even poignant movie, it is actually very predictableand cheesy. I expected more with a seemingly good cast, but thisfilm is definitely one of Julia Roberts' lows. The script isweak; almost all of the lines in the so-called "touching" scenesare over-used and cliché. The best thing about this movie is therather adorable little boy that plays the 6-year-old son ofSusan Sarandon. But don't pay seven dollars for him - rent themovie if you think it's really worth it. Some may find it sad,but most will see past

Stepmom is one of the most delightful movies in recent times ... ! It's a touching tale of maternal love that doesn't fail to move you no matter how many times you see it. It's a gem !Stepmom tells you the story of an American marriage that loses its spark with time and the man seeks love outside of it. This sensitive film deals with how the family handles the delicate situation --- at times, holding out bravely ... and at other times, buckling under the emotional trauma ! The other woman, very ably portrayed by Julia Roberts, is a genuinely good human being who tries to bond with her lovers' kids inspite of their mother's (and their own) initial bitterness towards her. The plot thickens when the mother of the kids, portrayed with finesse by Susan Sarandon, is found to have cancer. The mother's days in the world are now numbered and the family must learn to carry on without her ... ! Stepmom now paints a warm and endearing picture of how the members of this family reconcile their differences and stand united and strong in the face of this crisis.It would be UNFAIR if I rated this one anything less than 9 ... !

Review title: Ups and downs but overall good
Review_body: My first time watching this movie and enjoyed it on the whole. As others have mentioned the main characters are selfish and self-absorbed but this made it real for me and I can imagine feeling the same as Susan Sarandon's character if the same thing happened to me. I found it very similar to the ITV 2005 Movie "Walk away and I Stumble" which I found far superior. Check it out if you get the chance.

Review title: One of the best of Susan Sarondon
Review_body: Susan Sarondon makes an indelible mark in this movie like she always does. Though the movie seemingly captured the emotional difficulties of Julia's rather than Susan's character, I felt it was the emotional toughness of Susan that binds this entire movie together. The movie's centerpiece is the relationship between the two women, but Ed Harris's character could have been given little more prominence; I felt he went through the turmoil more than the two women combined. Julia is strong yet vulnerable; she shows her resolve to win over the children's hearts more than once, and she does.But ultimately, it is Susan who scores over. Every time Anna and Ben (her children) look up to her, she sets an example of how a mother should be. In the opening scene, when she says "I'll handle it from here", it becomes clear that she is going to handle the film as well. When she discloses her illness to her children, Anna goes wild that Susan didn't tell her earlier, but Susan knows that she'll eventually accept it. Despite all her toughness, she shows she is one among us by accepting her fear that her children might forget her. Finally she knows that her children are ready to accept Isabel (Julia), so she accepts her as well.I won't accept Susan's character any other way.

As a stepmom, I have quite a few things to say about this film. I think this is one of the worst films the great Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts have ever been in. This is basically about a man who is divorced with 2 kids who has a new, much younger girlfriend. I don't want to explain everything about the movie, just a few annoying points. First of all, the biological mother played by Sarandon lives in an incredibly beautiful and expensive home in Connecticut. She also has lots of land and horses. Sarandon apparently does not work either. The father played by Harris lives in the city in another incredibly beautiful and expensive place and they all drive expensive cars. How is this possible? With the bio-mom receiving the house, the child support and alimony payments it's a wonder he is not living in a 1 bedroom apartment. According to the way everybody is living, he must be a multi millionaire. Of course the new girlfriend, Roberts, is a trendy fashion photographer. Uygh. It seems everybody has lots of money. That is what irks me, because along with all the drama involved in being part of a blended family, one major problem is money. Ex- wives taking their ex-husbands back to court for more support, etc.. The struggles of the second family to make ends meet because 30% of the fathers income is going to his ex-wife. Apparently this is not an issue here. Another thing is the ex-husband, Harris, meets his ex- wife, Sarandon for dinner to discuss the fact that he will be asking his girlfriend, Roberts, to marry him. Come on. I can understand telling the bio-mom before you tell the kids, but telling her before you give your girlfriend the ring? It was like he was asking permission from his ex-wife to ask his girlfriend to marry him. It's so nice that ex-spouses can get along so well. Detect sarcasm. Oooh, if I found out my fiancé did that he'd be in a world of trouble. Another thing that irked me was that Roberts received a call on the job to pick up her future stepson at school. Apparently, the mom and dad could not do it and nobody else was available. I believe you have to be on a list at the school to be allowed to remove children for the safety of the kids. How did the fathers girlfriend get on that list? Please. So she risks her job to pick up a child that she is not responsible for. She goes back to her photo shoot in the park with the kid, but he wanders off. He eventually gets found, but when the bio mom finds out she is furious, and files a restraining order against Roberts. Huh? How about reprimanding the kid for wandering off when he was specifically told not to, and then not allowing Roberts to take responsibility for the kids ever again? If Roberts lives with the kids father, a restraining order seems quite ridiculous. I have to say, that this film shows a fantasy that most stepmoms have when dealing with unreasonable, jealous ex-wives. That fantasy is the bio mom dying. Yes, Sarandon has cancer and is going to die. How wonderful that would be for so many non custodial stepmoms, no more alimony, child support payments, a hefty life insurance policy payout, and no more controlling ex-wife poisioning the kids against their father and stepmom. But this is a fantasy, not reality. This film ends up not about being a stepmom and having a successful family, but tying up loose ends and preparing the kids for having a replacement mom when the bio mom dies.

Stepmom has touched my heart. It made me cry and laugh the first time I saw it. It didn't jump scene to scene like some movies, it flowed. Every part had to do with something that came before or comes after. They story will touch hearts across the world. It was touching! I saw it about 4 or 5 times. Review title: Way too much. Way over the top.
Review_body: I understand they're going for weeper here, but come on.  You get the impression that they'll throw in anything just to make the audience cry. "That tearful farewell speech didn't get to you?  Really?  Hmmm...let's see. We could shoot that puppy Julia Roberts got the kids at the beginning of the movie, would that do it for you?"  I think the film would have been much stronger had they not pushed the proverbial hanky quite so far.  Which is a shame, because this movie had potential, but the sentimentality gets pushed to the ridiculous, and ruins any credibility it had with me.

Review title: Great acting with a poor script
Review_body: This movie began poorly with such inane dialogue, I cringed on numerous occasions. Yet the actors took on the script, carried it through its painful inadequacies, and told a nice story. Fortunately, the storyline improved as it built up steam until it actually became almost believable, and it finished with a strong, though predictable ending. I would recommend this film as a good date movie.

ONLY COMMENT I'D LIKE TO MAKE IS THAT ED HARRIS IS ONE OF THE FINEST ACTORS OF OUR TIME.  IN THIS MOVIE, HE STEALS EVERY SCENE AND IS IMPACTFUL AS A DIVORCEE COPING WITH AN EX-WIFE AND A NEW GIRLFRIEND.  HIS PART IS SMALL BUT VERY EFFECTIVE.  I'D WATCH THIS MOVIE AGAIN, JUST TO WATCH A FINE ACTOR PLAY A SMALL BUT IMPORTANT PART.

The movie was filled with good actors but it just didn't make it.  The melodrama was overdone and it was too long for its simple plot.  I was disappointed and very glad I hadn't talked my husband into coming with me. The thing that makes me laugh is that had it been a tv movie it would have been laughed at by the critics.  As a multi-million dollar Hollywood extravaganza, the critics have tried hard to be kind.  They've tried too hard, those who follow the hype will be quite disappointed and find it hard to sit through to the "one more tear" end.

The child stars of this movie stole the show.  While all of the acting was excellent, the two younger stars, Jena Malone & Liam Aiken did a fantastic job.  I went with my family and the kids really enjoyed children's characters.As for the plot it was very good but not at all what I expected.  We had gone to what we thought would be a light hearted movie and found instead a real tear-jerker.  My kids (boys aged 9, 12 & 15) found it to be a bit long. The youngest waited patiently for it to end.  My wife cried a lot & complained that she didn't know to bring tissues.  None of us expected it to be so sad.

The family dynamics in this film were very real.  Susan Sarandon is a very talented actress and exhibits her talents splendidly within this film. However, Julia Roberts' talents were equal in depth.  Ed Harris, as always, did a great job. This one will jerk tears out of the most dry eyes in the audience.
This heart warming tale was sad and truthful. I really enjoyed it.

Review title: Sarandon deserves Oscar for portrayal of Mother Theresa
Review_body: Was this film the result of a guilty conscience or just wishful thinking? The sweetness and light, caring and sharing tend toward the hypoglycemic end of the scale.Great acting, though!  Sarandon, as usual, was superb.  Julia Roberts was probably her best since Mystic Pizza.  Ed Harris was the weakest of the cast, most likely due to the fact that he had an exceptionally unrealistic role to portray... the great guy who dumps his wife, gets her to condone his new relationship, then gets all the women in his life loving and hugging one another.  Pretty heady stuff.  Don't forget to avoid the candy counter on this one... it's far too sweet already.

Review title: TREMENDOUS MOVIE, SARANDON AND ROBERTS ARE GREAT
Review_body: Stepmom is a movie that takes you through a wide range of emotions. One minute you are laughing and the next your butter stained popcorn napkin is soaked with your tears.  Julia Roberts proves how versatile of an actress she is.  Not since Steel Magnolias has she taken such a dramatic role. Susan Sarandon is, well, let's face it, Susan.  She is one of the best actresses Hollywood has to offer.  She is well deserving of her Golden Globe nomination and is sure be nominated for an Oscar.  Tremendous job, Susan! Ed Harris, in a very minor role, does a great job of playing Sarandon's ex-husband and Roberts' fiancee.  All around this show is one of my favourites and not since Titanic have I cried so much.  What do the critics know?  Not as much as the audience.  That's why I give this movie FOUR AND A HALF OUT OF FIVE STARS.

Review title: The Greatest Drama of All Times.
Review_body: I loved the movie. I was overwhelmed by the sensibility of Chris Columbus, and how this movie gave us so many messages for real life, such as a family relationship and education of kids. But the most important thing, is that leaves you with the question: How would you handle a terrible disease such as Cancer? I enjoyed it so much, I will buy it as soon as it gets out.

This movie is about an American family caught in the troubles of marriage. The marriage is broke and the kids are in the middle of no where, as their dad wants to marry his girl friend. The events turn interestingly touching as Julia Roberts acted very well in the role of a step mother. Susan's action is also wonderful. The high light of the movie is the young kid's action. One dialogue to show his action:"mom! I will hate her, if you want me to". Isn't it really cool and touching ? Overall, a very good movie worth watching once!!

This movie is a real tearjerker. I cried the whole entire time! Julia Roberts and Susan Surandon's acting was magnificent. I recommend this for the whole family. The film seems so realistic. Its my personal favorite!

This is a real tear jerker, but also a heart-warming movie with several amusing scenes. Susan Sarandon and Julia Roberts do a wonderful job in portraying the rivaling ex-wife and new girlfriend. Ed Harris does great in his role of father. The scene where he explains to his kids why he fell out of love with their mother, but will always love them is very touching. Liam Aiken as "Ben" provides alot of humour in the movie. I like the scene where he thinks he has put a spell on his step-mom. Too cute. I love the actors in this movie and one of the reasons why I have watched it several times.

As a Comedy, it stunk. It had only a couple of funny moments that were shown in the trailers - no other funny parts...In actuality, it is a tear jerker. I don't know why they classify it as Comedy or why the trailers gave the impression of a Comedy. As a real stepmom, myself, I was hoping to see a lighter-side comedy about relationships that can be difficult and sometimes pretty tough and even heartbreaking; instead, it was about a relationship that was forced/forged through tragedy - not much to laugh about in the tragic second half of the movie.That being said, it was well written and well executed and as a Drama it was really good. The acting was superb and the writing was excellent. I was disappointed because I had been in the mood for a Comedy when I watched it.

A beautiful, yet somewhat heartbreaking story about a stepmother whom is struggling with the new world of being a mother while trying to keep up with her promising career. Not without difficulty.Whenever I watch this movie I get stuck, it totally gets me under its' spell and I find myself admiring the good acting, the casting that makes this movie what it is and the storyline. It's one of the best movies I have ever watched and I can assure you that tears will fall if you're into romantic, feel good-movies :')

I wish there s more than 10 to rate this movie i guess this is my fav movie ever i ve watched this movie over 100 times and i ll watch another 100 times love it

Whether you're susceptible to crying at movies or not, you'll enjoy this picture.  The performances by Sarandon, Roberts, and Malone (Anna) were particularly good.  The three age groups interacting was done very well.  Susan Sarandon is an excellent actress and has been around for some time. Julia Roberts seems to be getting better with each new film. This time she was outstanding.  The dialog between the three women was especially well written; very real, not phony at all.  Each played a very strong role.  Ed Harris and the little boy were in supporting roles even though they were an important part of the story.  I'd recommend this film to all and will see it again.

Someone in another comment said something about this being a science fiction...what?? how was it science fiction? i don't see how it could possibly be in the future.Anyway, i thought it was really good. a little long, but i liked it a lot. Parts were soooo sad, actually only one part, but i won't say why!! :)

From the preview, you might think that this movie is lighthearted. At least that is what I thought. I was wrong, very wrong. The drama came as a big shock as I was expecting something completely different. Be ready for tears, especially if you're a mom (which I'm not, but I saw the people around me). The movie, however, was preety good. The acting was really good, as could be expected by the two actresses and Ed Harris. The story was engaging and did manage to give the viewer a good insight into both of the main characters' minds. The little boy in it was cute and managed to give out a few laughs but I couldn't help but think that they were trying to recreate the little kid from Jerry Maguire. So it's not Oscar material (except for maybe the acting, Roberts was particularly surprising) but it's a good Drama and worth the watch. However, don't go as I did, expecting a lighthearted movie or you will be disappointed.

Review title: First half is good, second half is total cop-out!
Review_body: This movie could have been so much better. If it were not for "cancer", a lot of marginal screen writers would be out of work. Killing off the mother instead of developing the dynamic relationship that would have had to evolve between the stepmom and the mom was just plain lazy writing!

Review title: Uneven pacing and horrible writing bog down what could have been a good movie.
Review_body: Stepmom is unable to overcome it's "movie-of-the-week" script.  The talented cast is weighed under by weak direction and a predictable script that is seldom funny or moving.

Review title: Bring a box of tissues and watch the oscar-caliber performance by Sarandon, who should win best actress
Review_body: The all-star cast of this movie makes it well worth a visit to the movie theater and the stock you'll have to buy in tissue companies.  Susan Sarandon's performance is breathtaking - she is perhaps one of the best actresses of our time. Eschewing vanity for performance, her acting is enhanced by her lack of external adornment.  She sparkles on her own, but with outstanding performances by Julia Roberts (perfect as the new stepmom) and Ed Harris (his face is so wonderfully expressive - "What will we do without you?"), the entire movie is made even better.  The child actors in this film are fabulous.  In a word, this movie is fine, MIGHTY fine.

Review title: I have seen 3000 movies in my lifetime. Stepmom was the first I ever walked out of in my life.
Review_body: Stepmom after being hyped by its two stars for the past month was without any doubts the worst movie I have ever seen. It replaced that horror of horrors "Body Guard". The characters were unlikeable the plot was non-existent and the dialog could have been written by a high school freshman. Every one from stars,who by the way were executive producers (thus the reason for the hype), to the director should be held responsible for putting this piece of trash in theatres. The only redeeming factor from the entire miserable process was that Ed Harris only embarrassed himself three maybe four times. Two words say it all..."IT STUNK" .

Good drama with good acting by Sarandon and Roberts and the children. Wasn't prepared for it to be as sad as it was.  As a mother myself, some of scenes were heart-wrenching to say the least! The only complaint I have is that the movie made a couple of stabs at working mothers that made me flinch a little.  In one scene Jackie pretty much states that working mothers are too selfish to be good mothers; that 'good' mothers would stay home with the kids.  Then, Isabel's boss accuses her of being unfocused, etc. indicating that a working mother can't focus on her work because she's worrying about her kids.  Both scenes sort of made me feel like working mothers can't be good mothers OR good workers.  Anyway, good drama, real tear-jerker, loved Jackie's house!

Review title: You'll leave with red eyes but satisfied.
Review_body: I just went to see this yesterday with my friends and I loved it! It was so good! I love Julia Roberts and Susan Sarnadon and they were excellent. They really made it worth seeing. It's really touching and makes you think. I went home and gave my mom a big hug. The acting was wonderful and you have a good time too. It's not one of those movies where it's all heartbreak.  Even though you know what will happen once you leave, you leave satisfied and happy.  The little boy who ever he was was adorable too! And the greatest part, as my friends and I left the theater and went back into the mall, we spent the rest of the afternoon singing: Ain't no mountain high enough!

Review title: a chick-flick,but a boyfriend or husband can come along
Review_body: Stepmom is a real chick-flick, if I had been a guy, my comments on this movie would definitely have been different. It's true, towards the end you can predict almost every word, especially coming out of the mouth of Susan Sarandon. But being a real chick-flick lover I didn't really care.This movie had everything: comedy, romance, and drama, only the action was missing. Julia Roberts was a great stepmom, Susan Sarandon played a wonderful jealous and over-worried mom. But I have to say too, ... the kids, and in particular Liam Aiken (Ben), stole the show. The whole theatre was filled with "oooooooohh's" and "aaaaaaaah's" the moment the little boy came on the screen. I do not agree with the people who would rate Stepmom as 'awefull', though I wouldn't rate it excellent myself due to the predictions. Stepmom is just one of those movies you go and see on a Sunday afternoon, when there's nothing else to do.

Review title: The Best Freakin' Movie In THIS WORLD!!!!
Review_body: This movie....is just the best, the most, dramatic, piece of work!!I loved Jena Malone (anna)and the rest, they were just awesome, i would now like to say that Stepmom is by far the best movie this year!!

This is strictly a woman's film, lots of female interaction between Mom, fiance' and daughter.  Son livened things up a bit, a true "comic relief". Ed Harris is good, but not a major player.  Saranson very melodramatic.  I would recommend this to all my friends, but leave the guys out.

Review title: A Great movie, but don't forget you tissues.
Review_body: A Great movie, but don't forget your box of tissues. Wonderful acting. Definitely hits close to home.

I didn't think Stepmom would be so intense and so full of deep feelings. Certainly, you're going to laugh but the main idea is to really reach us deeply. For sensible hearts, prepare for the tears. A very nice movie, I strongly recommend it.

I was really surprised by this movie. I was expecting a comedy, but it was a real tearjerker. The acting was great, and they did a good job of portraying normal reactions for things like their dad getting remarried, as opposed to the "perfect" kids we often see on TV and in the movies. Julia Roberts and Susan Sarandon were wonderful, as was Ed Harris. Jena Malone, who I haven't seen in anything else, did a great job.

Awful film - predictable in the extreme, and an unashamed rip off of the thousands of other mindless tear-jerker films out there.  Yet again Julia Roberts managed to go through an entire film looking like she is just about to burst out crying.The absolute worst thing about this film is the drawn out "tear jerker" scenes.  The fact that Sarandon's character has got two kids means the mandatory awful farewell scene "you will always carry me in your heart" is actually repeated as the kids are wheeled in one at a time.Spend two hours cutting your toenails - it's more enjoyable.

When i saw this film, i was expecting it to be not good but was i wrong, this film is a real "tearjearker", and for the sad scenes, i could not stop crying, and i am 19 and male Susan and Julia give wonderful performances, and Ben Aitken who plays the kid Ben, makes the movie shines brightlySusan who plays Jackie, plays her role perfectly as a woman dying of cancer, and how she deals with it, and finally excepting Isabelle as part of the family Julia as Isabelle plays it well,in trying to win over the kids affection. I gave this movie a rating of 4 - 2 for Julia Roberts and 2 for Susan Sarandon as their performances were great as always.  Unfortunately the rest of the movie was terrible.  Why does Hollywood have to include cancer as a co-star in movies.  After going through 3 cancer-related deaths in my family, I can live without that much realism in movies.  Couldn't Mom and Stepmom have resolved their issues in another way - couldn't one of the kids have gotten lost and Julia and Susan worked together to find them?After this movie, I have made a point of finding out if a movie is a "cancer movie" before going and if there is even a hint of it, forget it.

Review title: You will laugh so hard you'll cry
Review_body: When watching this film I often laughed, but it is not like you think.  This film was horrible.  It is hard to believe it took five screen writers to make this film.  The dialogue by itself was enough to make cringe.  And as for the plot, it seems that Hollywood as developed a death equals tears theory.  Writers, if they want audiences to cry, simply kill someone.  The same technique was used in Patch Adams, another stinker.  Frankly, I think it is crap.  Films should be subtle and not force its tears on viewers like an used car salesmen.  Maybe I am just cold at heart, but i just don't buy it.
For a "chick flick" it's great.  My only complaints would be that it's a bit predictable, a bit long, and Sarandon is too much of a bitch such that her character becomes less believable.

Review title: Not the greatest movie...but one of the most heartfelt.
Review_body: I expected a very fun situational comedy; instead I got a very serious movie, with little to laugh about.  That's not necessarily a bad thing, just not what I expected.  I have to admit a lump was in my throat by the time the credits rolled.  I enjoyed it and would watch it again, but it just surprised me with it's tone.....

Review title: A Stepmom review from a fan!
Review_body: I loved this movie! If you are in the mood for a tear jerker movie, this is the movie too see. Julia Roberts and Susan Sarandon are remarkable together. This is the absolute best I have seen Julia Roberts act and this movie defiantly brings out her talent. Susan Sarandon can make any movie good. But she delivers outstanding effort to make her character relate to other women who have had the problems that Susan's character faces. This movie is of course a 10 out of 10! Julia Roberts and Susan Sarandon will make you laugh now and then, but they will also make you cry with the difficulties that they face together on screen. Stepmom is a movie you'll enjoy and "always always" remember as a movie that filled your heart. So if you haven't seen Stepmom yet...go and see it! You'll be glad that you did.

Review title: Do NOT watch this movie -- it is one of the WORST ever...
Review_body: Susan Sarandon and Ed Harris are very good actors, but this movie is one of the sappiest pieces of $%&* I have ever had the displeasure of seeing. There were several times where I had to yell out loud in pain from the sheer corniness of it, and I was watching it by myself. It is pure torture, I HATED it SO MUCH...it almost defies description. The story line is very sad in that typical tear-jerker kind of way, and Julia Roberts (who in some scenes looks like she is wearing a wig made of hay) is no great prize of an actress, in my opinion. I only rented this, despite my better judgement, because I thought there might be some redeeming aspect to it. Would that this were the case. It is a COLOSSAL waste of time. The actress playing the daughter does a reasonably good job also, but that is about all this thing has going for it.

Review title: This is the first time I have seen this movie Stepmother
Review_body: I have never cried mixed tears of joy, anger, and sadness. So many emotions in 2 and a half hours. I called my children (they were in bed, and had to be up early in the morning for work). I just needed to tell them that I loved them. That movie has touched my heart like no other, and it was very easy to forget these were actor.s. I grew emotionally attached to every person in the film. I can honestly say that I have never been so emotionally involved in any movie like this one. It grabbed every emotion in my heart. When the credits scrolled, I just lay back on my couch, and thought about every piece in the scenes, and relived them in my mind. I know the movie is from 1998, and its not new, but, its brand new to me, and the only reason why I wouldn't see it again is because its so heart wrenching. Wonderful wonderful film. Thankyou for this movie.

Review title: A new women in a previously married man's life creates stress for both his children and his ex-wife.
Review_body: This was a very enjoyable film to watch. This must be due to the fact that it's bright and filled with life through Liam Aiken's character Ben. It's also lighthearted through the new love emerging between Julia Robert's character, Isabel, and the two children, not to mention her relationship with Luke, played by Ed Harris.The movie is also done well through the visual appeal that it holds. The beginning of the story is in late summer and ends at Christmas. The entirety of the film's scenes all use various camera angles and shots. This helps the viewer to be involved in the story and get to know the characters.The topic of Stepmom was very difficult because of Susan Sarandon's character's fight with cancer. The most touching scenes were those of her and her children during Christmas. It was highly emotional when she talked to her daughter about how she would aways be there with her, if the daughter let her. The scene was so poignant because most daughters could clearly picture herself in Anna, the daughter's shoes, or even the mother's.All in all, this is a great movie which deals with two major issues. Even the film is from 1998, it's still just as prevalent ten years later.

Review title: I loved every bit of it
Review_body: I loved every bit of it. I remember watching this together with my whole family and hugging my mom at the end. The love they show for their mother is gold-worthy. It's also a realistic movie which makes it even better. Their mother doesn't like the stepmother at first because she still loves her ex-husband and she hopes to get back together but when she sees that their love is real she puts her hate aside and just tries to live through it all. The fact that the mother accepts the fact that another woman will take care of her children when she's no longer there had me in tears. It's a real tearjerker and a really good movie to watch with the whole family. It's a movie that will stay in your mind and heart forever. If you haven't watched it yet, this is your chance. You'll thank me later.

Review title: Very heart breaking and heart warming at the same time
Review_body: It's a very meaningful movie that explores life, death, love, forgiveness, joy, hope, jealousy, fear and pain from different angles from the angle of a mother, a lover, a parent and a child. The most interesting thing I found from this movie was the unconventional and definitely unintended friendship between the mother and stepmum. The selfless love they have for their spouse and the kids was so heart warming. It's a movie that will pull heart strings, put a heart warming smile to your face and leave you feeling inspired to expand your heart and mind to love others more, especially those in our lives who are hard.

I saw this after getting a leukemia diagnosis..watched it alone in a hotel room..I had a son and daughter...my son used to say the same things to me...great set-up for tears right?? Don't understand the ease with which Luke is able to just dump his family for Isabelle who doesn't seem to have any clothes other than leather or a burgundy sweater set...sorry these folks don't exist in real life. Why marry Luke Isabelle?? He has a young son but just "falls" out of love with his wife and leaves them?? I cry bullshit. Luke's answers are so maniacally 1 dimensional it frustrated me....and she is supposed to be some great photographer but is just willing to give up her career? Did anyone think the daughter was such a brat because Mom had issues when life focused on someone other than her? Too many questions, pretty house - pretty topical stuff but too many selfish adults in one movie to make any sense.

Well what can I say? I don't often post comments on websites like this but it has to be said that the acting was superb and Jena Malone and Susan Suranden were sensational together! you would really think they were mother and daughter. The rest of the cast really brought it to life, you would also think that there was an actual history there, and it all made sense. Sometimes I felt that the characters were a bit snappy towards each other but that is what they call a great writer and an excellent cast! I was brought to tears with this movie and that rarely happens, I would see it a million times and still be touched. I am no professional critic but I know what I like and I liked this very much. To all those who gave it the finger I say GET A LIFE! Chris
